name: Ol Pejeta Conservancy
shortDescription: East Africa's largest black rhino sanctuary with the world's last two northern white rhinos, the only place in Kenya to see chimpanzees, and the most diverse activities of any conservancy.
fullDescription:
Ol Pejeta Conservancy is a 360 km¬≤ not-for-profit wildlife conservancy in Central Kenya's Laikipia County, situated on the equator west of Nanyuki, between the foothills of the Aberdares and Mount Kenya. The Conservancy works to conserve wildlife, provide a sanctuary for great apes, and generate income through wildlife tourism for re-investment in conservation and community development.

The Conservancy boasts the largest black rhinoceros sanctuary in East Africa, with over 130 critically endangered black rhinos roaming within a secure and monitored habitat. Most notably, it also houses the two last remaining northern white rhinos in the world, who were moved here from Dv≈Ør Kr√°lov√© Zoo in the Czech Republic, making Ol Pejeta a critical frontline in the fight against extinction.

The Sweetwaters Chimpanzee Sanctuary is situated here, providing a haven for orphaned, abandoned, and rescued chimpanzees. It is the only place in Kenya where chimpanzees can be seen. The Sanctuary opened in 1993 through a partnership between the Ol Pejeta Conservancy, Kenya Wildlife Service, and the Jane Goodall Institute, and currently provides lifelong refuge to 43 chimpanzees rescued from traumatic situations across west and central Africa.

Ol Pejeta offers the most activities available of all the parks and conservancies in Kenya, making it perfect for active travelers seeking diverse wildlife experiences beyond traditional game drives.
activities: Visit the Endangered Species Enclosure with the last northern white rhinos
Lion tracking with expert guides and GPS equipment
Night game drives to spot nocturnal predators
Guided bush walks with armed rangers
Community visits to local schools and projects
